page.title: 09Longage Farm: dairy changes
page.content: Until six years ago Mr Ridley-Day was a dairy farmer with a herd of Guernsey cows. Guernsey cows give rich creamy milk and as people became more aware of the effects of cholesterol in such milk the demand for his milk lessened and he was forced to stop dairy farming. The EEC encouraged dairy farmers to stop producing milk and he sold his herd to the government. Unfortunately the whole herd had to be destroyed. A dairy herd consists of many cows in order to get a lot of milk. Cows are milked two or three times a day. Modern dairy methods make it possible for milk, cream, butter and cheese to be produced cheaply. Todays milking machines are highly efficient, hygenic and easy to operate. The EEC have introduced milk quotas to reduce the amount of milk produced.
